stem: The nurse is preparing to administer an oral medication. Place the 'Three Checks' of medication administration in the correct logical order.

options.text: Check the medication label against the MAR when removing it from the storage area/drawer.
Document the administration in the electronic health record.
Check the medication label against the MAR at the client's bedside before administration.
Check the medication label against the MAR while preparing it (e.g., placing in a cup).

pedagogy.nclexCategory: Safety and Infection Prevention and Control

rationale.correct: The Three Checks provide a triple redundancy to stop errors. (1) Selection check. (2) Preparation check. (3) Bedside check. Documentation only happens *after* the patient has swallowed/received the drug.
rationale.incorrect: Documenting before administration ('Pre-charting') is a serious violation of nursing standards and safety.
clinicalPearls: Always use two patient identifiers (Name/DOB) at the bedside, even if you know the patient.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Never select an answer that involves documenting a medication *before* you give it. If the patient refuses, the record will be inaccurate.

reviewUnits.heading: The Five Rights (and more) of Medication Administration
reviewUnits.body: Nurses verify Right Patient, Drug, Dose, Route, and Time. Modern practice adds Right Documentation, Right Reason, and Right Response.
